This is an atomic structure of graphite. Graphite is a layered material made of carbon atoms, and a pencil lead is made of graphite.

By printing this material, you can understand the characteristics of graphite structure such as:

  • a single layer has honeycomb structure which is due to the sp2 bondings between carbon atoms,
  • interlayer distance is much larger than intralayer distance. This is because the interlayer coupling is not covalent bonding but the van der Waals interaction (or intermolecular force),
  • so, you can feel a van der Waals world by this material.

The stl file is made by Blender.
Just my own attempt

title: MiniExtruder for Prusa i3 (mini) and RepRapPro hot end

description.text:
I have tried to make a MiniExtruder-drive for RepRapPro-hotends fit to a standard Prusa i3 / i3 mini printer (I want to have a i3 mini in the near future). First tests looked good - let's see what the real printing jobs will look like.  
The extruder has mounting holes for 24mm and 30mm mountings with M3-bolts. As my MiniExtruder this one also works with a Nema14 stepper motor.  
Need a matching hobbed bolt? Write a pm or an e-mail (3d.andy(AT)gmx.net).  
I have uploaded two stl-files: one with and one without support material for the motor flange and idler bearing.

The extruder drive is nearly the same as the original (from my MiniExtruder). Just without the bowden tongue and mounting screws. To use the RepRapPro hotend you will have to cut the bowden tube to fit to the extruder drive (see pictures).  
When assembling you will have to fix the heatsink and the fan at the very end (see pictures).

A simple, low profile baseball bat holder. Consists of a ring with a diameter of 36mm at its widest point, in the center. There's an opening in the front of the ring that is 28mm. This allows the baseball bat to sit secure in the ring, then be lifted up a few inches and pulled out through the opening to remove. There is a 2mm hole in the center of the back-plate to allow you to fasten the holder to something. Surprisingly, two 3M poster strips were able to support my ~2 lb bat on the wall.

title: Business card - Layer selective colour 3D printing

description.text:
I wanted to experiment using my Filament joiner to make prints that had different coloured finishing layers (at different heights) on an object.
A business card seemed a suitable object to start with as I could place things and text onto it and vary the height of each object.

This uses joined pieces of filament the correct length so colour changes happen on layers in the print, the text and objects on the business card are different heights (from 0.8mm to 3mm) so as each layer ends it has a different colour.
See my blog for further details.

comments.text: Over the top. This is really imaginative and now skilled too!

comments.text: How exactly did you figure out the lengths of filament to join. You used grep to split out the layers, then how did you figure out how long a filament would cover each layer?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text:
I don't know how he did it, but I might skeinforge the object from say layers 1-10 (carve tab) and read off the mass of plastic. Then make the first segment weight slightly more. Then skeinforge layers 11-14 or whatever. Continue to build the joined filament in this manner. Just make sure each color layer is at least 2 (probably
&
gt;=3) actual layers to take up some of the inaccuracies. Finally reskein the whole object and print.

comments.text: He explains it very well in his blog  :-D

comments.text: For those too lazy to click through his profile.

comments.text: um yeah I wasn't too lazy. I read the blog. He says he used grep to separate out the layers, but doesn't indicate how to figure out the lengths. He did not explain that part very well in his blog. I wonder, did you guys read the blog post?
comments.author: jasay

comments.text: Because he uses Skeinforge 41 he can just add up the lengths of filament indicated by each layer in the Gcode. ( All the E moves are actual lengths of filament being used ). So using Grep he adds up all the E values from each Layer and cuts a length of filament to match.

author: cope413

description.text:
Childhood favorite films.

I have no idea is this will work as a flute or instrument, but it would make a pretty cool prop print.

I make a lot of things with PVC pipe. Pipe is hard to drill on a drill press because it likes to try and roll away. This device cradles three different size of pipe - 1/4" CPVC, 1/2" PVC, and 3/4" PVC (diameters are easily changed). It has three holes on each pipe, each marked with a vertical indicator (this lets you look at straight at the tube from the front to tell if your drill bit is centered). It has grooves for measuring, currently at 5mm (easily changed (I work with a mixture of metric and imperial units)).

comments.text: Even though it's just a jig, probably one of my nicest prints :) Took 11 hours on a CR-10S. But super clean.  May I now ask a question after the glowing review? :) If I wanted to change the 1/2 holes to 2" spacing, what is the easiest way to do this without really mucking up your design?

Does your flower pot lean?
Want it leveled?
Make a wedge that fits your garden.

How to measure:

1. Measure Pot diameter,

take the lowest point to the highest point of the bottom diameter.
3 wedges will be created

  • the highest goes in at the lowest point
  • 2 smaller ones at 90 degree angle, to stop the wobble of the pot

    2. Measure the gap

    a) put a wood bar on the top of the pot, touching the highest point at the rim
    b) put a spirit level on the wood of the highest point/rim and the lowest point.
    c) lift the spirit level, until level, the resting point should be highest of the pot
    d) measure the gap,
    at the diameter distance away from the resting point of the highest point
    down to the wood bar

3. Decide about the block size of the wedge.

The wedge should have a good depth to the pot rim rests on it.
The width give stability against wobbling.

4. You might want to have an edge at the outer end

It can prevent slipping off of the pot. Decide on width of the edge and it's height.

Printing Instructions:

Work in Progress:

The slicer software allowed to split the stl, need to fit them onto a normal sized printer.

The idea behind is:

I suggest to print the wedges on the side,
give good surfaces, support not needed, and also the force lines align to edge, so they aren't easily delaminated.

Printing it upside down, gives nicer the wedge a nicer bottom,
and is still rough enough not to slip.
Note: if printed with edge, an upside down print requires good gap spanning, support material is difficult to remove. So I printed it without support.

Infill

30% infill will support very heavy item,
20% infills worked good for 60 cm high pot filled with soil.

glue the knob on the lid

Some of the people with whom I work lack sensation in their fingers (peripheral neuropathy) as well as being visually impaired. They can feel big things, but small variations in texture are outside their perception.

They become isolated because they can not dial a phone accurately. There are devices that can help people with poor dexterity/memory dial a phone (such as the photo dialer here: http://www.amazon.com/Innovative-Technology-Electronics-Corp-Button/dp/B005UZMQNY ). People who are visually impaired can use these by counting the grid (e.g. Aunt Margaret is at [1,3]), but people who can not feel AND can not see the buttons are stuck.

This file creates tiles which can be glued to the "Big Button Photo Dialer", thus giving a set of tactile markers that can be felt (either with the pad of the finger, or by dragging a fingernail across the marker), thus they can use the dialer to call up to 12 people.

It also makes an awesome torture test / calibration test for a 3D printer due to lots of thin walls and islands.

title: E3D v6 hotend mount for 3D Touch

description.text:
This is a 2 piece clamshell clamp to mount an E3D v6 head into a BFB 3d Touch printer. May also work on a 3DS CubeX if they use the same mounting holes, I don't know.

UPDATE v1.1
Edges of model sliced off to allow the part to fit between the bearing holders on the head carriage.

It's a half inch thick, and 45mm in diameter. I printed mine with 100% fill, no support, out of PETg at .250mm layer height. It came out a bit lumpy, my printer doesn't like 100% fill for some reason. You will also need 5 brass M3 threaded inserts and M3 bolts.

As a side note, the stock E3D 100k Ohm thermistor won't work with the 3D Touch, you'll need a 230k Ohm thermistor, although I'm told a 200k will also work.

comments.text: Do you have any pictures of your set up and how you attached it to your printer?  Trying to upgrade my 3D Touch printer with your design.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Hi, I've put up a photo of it in place. It's not very tricky, it just replaces your existing hotend using the same 3 bolts.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Interesting.... I have a BFB 3D touch and the hot end on one of the extruders has been throwing temp errors, so I'm thinking of replacing it.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Yeah, I had the same thing. The mortar like material around the nozzle started crumbling and the leads of the thermistor began shorting out intermittently. The V6 works great, although I've had to employ some jiggery pokery to get the tip down to the same level as the stock nozzles so I can print with it. The print results are so much improved that now I'm ordering 2 more V6s to replace the other stock nozzles.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Thanks! I figured as much, since Axon is annoying slow and restrictive.  3D Systems also way overprices their products ($140 for a new hot end), so I'm really glad I found your project.
comments.author: duke

comments.text: I did the mount in 123D Design. It gets the job done eventually, but coming from an AutoCad background, I know AutoDesk can do sooo much better than that.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Awesome.  Is the new design uploaded?
comments.author: duke

comments.text: Yep, it's good to go. I haven't printed the updated design yet because I'm still using the original one, so let me know if it doesn't work.
comments.author: Mattraptions

comments.text: Sweet.  I'd love to learn how exactly you were able to fabricate an aluminum heated print bed for your BFB (CNC?  Water Jet? Outsourced?)  and octoprint is definitely something I'm trying to incorporate into mine.
comments.author: duke

comments.text: The bed wasn't too tricky actually, I just went down to my local sheet metal fabricators and they sliced me off a rectangle of 6mm aluminium for a tenner. I did the cutout with a jigsaw and the holes with a cordless drill, just use the stock bed as a template. I got a 240v silicone bed heater and a PID controller off eBay.
comments.author: Mattraptions

Not being able to leave well enough alone, I found that I needed to have partial surfaces of revolution. This thing adds the ability to specify starting and ending angles for the revolution (defaults to 0 to 360). That's kind of nice because for the simple cases where you are not intersecting with something at odd angles, you can simply generate the exact surface that you need, and call it a day. Included in this revision is an experiment to see if the built-in 'rotate_extrude' could do a better job of things. Although it does play nicely with the CSG operations while viewing, it does not generate 2-manifold structures (and thus, no .stl files). I'm thinking maybe I need to overlap surfaces or something, rather than calculating exact vertices. At any rate, I thought of adding rotation about an arbitrary line, as a final step, but really, that's easily achieved in OpenScad, so this might be the end of the line for these routines. Isn't it amazing what can be done with OpenScad!! Blog Entry: http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/07/01/revolutionary-surfaces-with-openscad/

1) Download all the .scad files
2) Play with test_revoloids.scad
3) Create pretty pictures
4) Turn them into .stl
5) Print/combine
6) Rejoice!

comments.text: My girlfriend has her ears stretched to about 22-24mm and has been asking me if it were possible to print earrings to fit her that look similar to these. She wants something that looks like /thing:1153959 but big enough to fit her ear.

comments.text: Hi there! I used Autodesk Fusion 360. It's fairly easy to make earrings with it - just make a pipe with whatever basic shape you want and then sculpt it to make sections thick or thin. description.text:
Here the laser cut drawings of the casing for the CCC Radio. For every one who couldn't get the casing at the Chaos Communication Camp 2015, because at the Fablab Truck we ran out of materials.

You can cut it now at your local Fablab, Hacker- or Makerspace.

The CCCradio_layouts_basics file is best for cutting acrylic. You can use a transparent Top, so you still see the leds and radio shape.

The CCCradio_engraving_lies file is for cutting a wooden casing. Here I made holes for the leds and an engraving of the radio shape.

As distance holders we used laser cut washers, cut from the same material as the casing. You need 16 washers per casing.

You can assemble it by using 25mm M3 bolds and nuts or use small tyraps instead.

We used 3mm thick material.
The best team in the Premier League (OK only my opinion). Swansea City Football Club Badge. 3D Print it out and support the mighty Swans. Enjoy.

title: USB Relay Box (save energy) - Caja de reles por USB (ahorra energia)

description.text:
UPDATE 19/05/2016
New Smaller version without suko plug. Files: Mini tapa y mini cuerpo.
The screws for the cover in the MINI version are typical computer box ones (easy to have some around the house)

Save energy making all your computer devices turn TOTALY off (not standby mode) when u shutdown the computer. Read the Instructions for detailed info.
Printers, routers, desktop lights, switches, speakers, mixers , usb hugs ...
I wait for your questions, suggestions and upgrades.

Ahorra energia haciendo que todos los aparatos se apaguen por completo (no en standby) cuando apagas el ordenador. Impresoras , router, lamparas de escritorio, switch, altavoces, equipos de musica, mezcladores, ladrones usb ...

Espero sus preguntas, sugerencias y mejoras

You will need:

  • Print box and cover.
  • Relay (use a good one, "dont play with fire")
  • bticino luna suko plug
  • male suko and good cable with ground
  • USB female type B port
  • some screws
    Conect all to the box, plug it to the current and usb port to your computer. Then all the devices (to the bticino plug useing a multi suko device): desktop lights, printers, router, monitor ..... all u want to turn off when u turn off computer.
    So when u turn on the computer all that devices will have current again and when u turn off computer all get off, saveing loads of energy at year (or time, turning off all of them one by one)

Notice some boards keep giving current to the USB ports when the computer is off. You can change this on BIOS or with a jumper on the main board, depends of the board, read the manual.

description.text:
Using festools Carvex PSC 420 Jig Saw you need to have an Allen wrench to adjust for different size saw blades. While the older model had a place in the base, the newer model hasn't. So I was wondering how to find a place to store the included 2.5mm allen key. The hex key holder can be placed directly underneath the rubber frame that is fixed to the battery back.
In case the allen wrench does not hold perfectly, bent it slightly that it will grip into the holder by itself.

I printed the part with Colorfabbs XT material with a 40% infill on an Ultimaker 2.
Up to now it holds the key secure and works fine.

This is a set of plastic snap-together blocks that was designed for a prototype universal constructor. You can see a simulation of a robot made from the blocks here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LumLzSQE5Vw You can get more info on the strengths and weaknesses of the actual physical plastic blocks here http://www.molecularassembler.com/KSRM/3.18.htm

The parts were originally made using polyurethane casting.  The files uploaded here have been modified to make them printer-friendly.  But I haven't tested if they actually print...
To make a part, you will need to print a top and a base.  The top and base then have to be glued together.  You can mix and match different tops and bases to make a variety of parts, including structural pieces, gears, racks, and so on.
SnapBlocks.zip contains 16 stl files in dimensions of millimeters
SnapBlocksAlibreSource.zip contains the source models in Alibre part format

description.text:
Inspired by www.thingiverse.com/thing:9771 from www.thingiverse.com/MakeALot.
While i found out a nice feature in OpenScad, i tested it to find out how fast i can create a object out of a idea. And it worked! 
I used this polygon generator program ( thingiverse.com/thing:9290 ) to create this object.

Runs in OpenScad.
Inside the source you will find a option to view the object normal or printable. With printable you need to print it twice and glue the parts together. I was to lazy of create some sort of click system because i didn't want to see any gap between the 2 parts. Anyway, maybe i will add later a click system because the hearts can be made hollow, so that you can put pills (or something else) inside. 
The bracelet diameter (inside) is +/- 7 cm, you need to scale it to make it smaller or larger.

A nut driver for a small cordless screwdriver.
Being made of plastic has the added advantage of acting as a clutch (when the plastic slips and squishes at high torques). I use it to loosely secure hose clamps and it has surprisingly met my needs quite well because there is a built in clutch (the plastic part slips loose a bit).
It is way easier to use this nut driver than a slotted screwdriver because the slot slipped out too often.

Made out of ABS on a Thingomatic with 100% infill.
You can alter the scad file to suit your needs ... especially the fit in the screwdriver which may be too loose for some applications.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iAB2ak1uuCR

description.text:
A technology refresh of my original Stratos glider, with dihedral hinge, washout wings, load dumping stress risers, an improved KF variant aerofoil, latch-up elevators, and 3D canopy. It all ads up to the glider I wish I could have bought when I was a kid...and a ridiculous amount of fun for 1250mm of ABS plastic. A Full sized variant that can be printed on a 100MM bed can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:300168 If your printer is dimensionally stable, check out my glueless design at : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158421 Also check out our ultralight, high aspect ratio variant, the Cumulus - for longer, slower flights and thermaling capability! see http://threedsy.com in the cloud fliers collection. With the (second - see above link) best glide ratio of any of my gliders, self stabilizing dihedral, and a wing design that opens up the flight envelope to high speeds without sacrificing glide, the Super Stratos has earned its place as my new favorite fun flyer. A little down bend in the elevators (after being latched up) will open up soaring loops, thermal riding, and 540 degree orbital flights. The Super Stratos is very responsive to rudder input. Video 1
Video 2 Launcher and tools: For instructions look at my glider instruction thing:1465700. For tips on printing glider wings, drop by my blog at threedsy.com and if you like our models, keep us designing for you instead of flipping burgers by purchasing one of our premium designs from the site! If you like my gliders, check out my other models here on thingiverse and more models and books I wrote on 3D Design and 3D Printing here at threedsy.com If you want to learn how to design amazing, highly functional designs for 3d printing, design and print useful repair parts, and generally print useful stuff faster, more reliably, and with less problems check out my books, Functional design for 3D printing and the Zombie Apocalypse Guide to 3D Printing on Amazon!

Plastic: ABS Layers: .20mm Fill: 25% Perimeters: 2 Solid Layers: 2 filament use / weight (3mm) : Approx 1250mm Orientation:
first layer lentghwise (0 degrees to fuselage), altrenate by 90 degrees. A 45 degree (or non right angle) axis will cause asymetrical wing warping under load (bad). Build Notes:
Allow to cool before carefully removing from build platform. The wings are easily deformed during removal, and must be absoultely symmetrical for proper flight. Removal with a very thin plastic spatula (print one!) is preferred. Test fit all parts and trim if necesary prior to final assembly with a very small amount of CA Glue. The dihedral joint is assembled by clamping along the top of the fuselage between the wings to establish dihedral angle. Remove any adhesions, test clamp and adust as necescary to achieve a symmetrical dihedral angle prior to fixing in place with CA Glue. Flight Notes: Launching is by hand or with a 1/16" to 1/8" rubber band. Test and adjust by hand launching first. A slight elevator - up reflex is required for non-inverted flight. This is accomplished by latching the elevons up on the relex tabs on the aft end of the fuselage. A tiny drop of glue will prevent the elevons from moving from their latched position. A slight down bend in the latched-up elevators will open up the flight envelope to higher energy flights. A gradual test/adjust cycle is recommended. To correct turning or spiraling, differential elevator control (elevon) is preferred, though some aileron bending may be needed if the wings are warped from improper bed removal. Carefully bend this in with finger pressure, but avoid creasing or excessive strain.

title: 3D Printed Case for Open Source Theremin

description.text:
Nice curved case that fits exactly an Arduino with an Open.Theremin.UNO shield.

The Open.Theremin.UNO is an arduino shield to build a real, playable theremin music instrument. The theremin is played with two antennas, one to control the pitch and one for volume. The electronic shield with two ports to connect the antennas comprises two heterodyne oscillators to measure the distance of the hand to the antenna just as the original theremin.

For source files and instructions or to buy a complete kit see:
http://www.gaudi.ch/OpenTheremin

Best to print in an upright Position.
Cut at 1/4" UNC thread to use a commercial camera stand.

A further refinement of the X-carriage,
This time no screws or cable ties, it all just pops together and prints fast. Features wiring loom support on the rear and integral wiring holes for fan wiring (neat) of the fore and aft fans. I have mounted my ducted fan on the front to cool the J-head barrel and a rear mounted fan to cool the work. I have gone for simple cable tie belt clamps and I used an inline belt tensioner to take up the slack. For best results Slide the LM8UU's in from the ends to prevent splitting, they will hold once in place.
Print it out at 40% fill and two or three perimeters.

comments.text: Discovered while repairing a friend's printer today, this carriage works well with the MBE extruder on a Mendel Prusa or variant. That extruder needs a very thin carriage to be able to protrude below it and with the reduced bearing holders on the under side it has additional clearance.

title: Super Pi Boy - a SNES capable Game Boy

description.text:
This is a remix based on the original Adafruit design. I decided to use as much real estate on the inside as possible. Unlike the original Game Boy, this unit has 4 buttons on the front and two buttons on the back. If you're up for a challenge, see my guide and build one for yourself.

See the thing files section for pdfs of both versions.

comments.text: Hey Derek, do you happen to have a wiring diagram for getting the TS2012 Amp hooked up in your piboy? I'm having trouble following along in your PDF about how the external jack, pi output, and potentiometer play together.
comments.author: juancgarcia

comments.text: I added a rough sketch to the pictures section
comments.author: juancgarcia

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: DerekSullivan

comments.text: I'll see if I can make one sometime this weekend.  In short the external jack on the Raspberry Pi connects to the potentiometer R and L + inputs.  The ground gets jumped along the way the whole circuit.  The outputs of the potentiometer and the ground then get connected to the headphone jack.  The headphone jack gets connected to the TS2012 with the positives going into the positive holes and the ground going into both negative holes.  Then the outputs of the amp go to the speakers.

comments.author: DavidLJW

comments.text: All the Powerboost 500 does is boost your voltage from 3.7V to 5V so the Raspberry Pi and the amp can be powered.  They will not work without it.  I don't think it's possible to play solely on the power of the charger unfortunately.  The lipo board is limited to 500mA and that's only if you solder the tab on it - otherwise it's 100mA and you definitely won't be able to power it from that. I could be wrong though.  I just know that when my battery died, I tried plugging it in and it wasn't enough.  I didn't solder that tab yet though.  Next time I wear out my batteries I'll give it a shot, but I have it apart right now trying to work out rev B
comments.author: DavidLJW

comments.text: Thanks for the info and link to the part, I live in the UK so may explain why I missed it.
comments.author: DerekSullivan

comments.text: Rev B will be better wire management and I'm eliminating the three protrusions that hold the L and R buttons in place.  As it is right now, it works fine, but putting the cover on is kind of difficult with all the wires in the way of the L and R boards.  In the new one I'll be capturing the L and R boards on the bottom half and the buttons will clip in.  I'm still a ways off though.  I originally tried it this way and it was hard to get the buttons to clip in place properly and stay aligned.
comments.author: DavidLJW

This is a cover plate and interface for the Mean-Well 12v 29A power supply. Part number for the power supply is S-350-12.

The 3 outputs I have are XT60 female and male, and banana plug connections. It was designed to operate RC LiPo battery chargers.

The XT60 screw in adapters were designed by mrorange26 and are here ... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:516420

The power connector is a standard screw in power adapter, and the snap in lighted switch should be standard as well.

The print is a tight fit, tight enough to hold it's own without mounting screws, but the design has a relief to anchor into the side.

Casing for a remote camera trigger.  The case fits nicely in a (small) hand.
There's cutouts for two push-buttons and a rocker switch.  Also a cutout for the cable to exit.

Print the 2 halves; fit the circuit; glue the halves together. (Make sure it works first!) Image is of prototype; working on finished trigger:
  • Printing at 60% fill
  • Clean cutouts (make sure buttons fit)
  • Acetone wash (& abs fill) to smooth out print
  • Test all electronics while waiting for plastic to cure
  • Sand and wipe-down casing to provide a better surface for rubberizer
  • Fit and hot-glue electronics (make sure to install a cable strain relief)
  • Test all electronics again
  • Glue/acetone casing halves together; sand seam
  • Mask off buttons/wire/etc; spray with rubberizer/plastidip
    • Wired it up as per: http://www.doc-diy.net/photo/eos_wired_remote/ 2011-07-14: Finished! I decided not to plastidip the casing. (The cap is glued slightly off center too; meh.) I used a 16 foot audio cable, giving me a large range to play with. Make sure when testing it that all your cables are good!

title: DJI Phantom 1.5 LED usb board external mount

description.text:
This is another one of my modification of Phantom 1 in Phantom 2 shell. It is all about mounting led usb board outside the case and not on back door. That way by adding Phantom 2 power cord for battery we can use P2 battery and still have info led. Also till now original shell of P2 is intact.

In this position there can be some issues in connecting via usb for those of you who have fpv transmitters. This will probably be problem for me also.

Summary:
pros:

  • external led usb board mount under rear left leg on one screw,
  • cable management,
  • no interference in shell,
    cons:
  • possible problems using usb cable with fpv transmitter mounted,
  • cable behind mount need some zip tie

For the time being, it works for me.

ps. after posting this project i have just realized incorrectly mounted top cover :P

Edit:

I have modified this design to support zip tie mount.
Also look at my remix with FPV antenna mount.

Printed in PLA 195/60 Celsius - 100% infill

Mount on leg inner screw. No need for longer one. Original works fine.
Cable for led going through leg hole by extension cord from Naza.

title: Printrbot Alu Extruder V2 Hot End Key

description.text:
Note: Make sure to rotate so that it prints flat! Sorry, I forgot to do that. Will change soon!

This piece fits into the bracket that holds the hot-end on the Printrbot Alu Extruder V2. It slides in and hold the hot-end in place without needing to use the tension screw. There is a hole to feed the screw through so that the bracket doesn't move.

We printed with Cura software on Printrbot Play using their standard PLA filament. It fits a little snug, but for me, that was the point.

Make sure to rotate so that it prints flat on your print bed with the notch facing up. Will upload a new version where that's fixed soon!

Shell thickness 0.4mm
Fill rate 20%
30mm/sec for our printer
We did print on a raft because no heated bed, but probably didn't need it.

The openings are just a hair on the small side and will require a small amount of sanding to make the parts fit. i will try to get a photo upload soon of the finished product. i have printed both parts and they turned out wonderful.the last few layers are rased so so you can print in a different color. i went with black and yellow and it is cool.

Edmonton 3D Prints web page:

www.edmonton3dprints.ca/

You can check out some of my other work on my FB page:
https://www.facebook.com/edmonton3dprints/

Thanks for your interest
Ian

title: HiFiBerry Digi + Raspberry Pi2 case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Case designed for a Raspberry Pi2 + HiFiBerry Digi shield.
I use mine as a dedicated Musicbox -> http://www.pimusicbox.com/

You can also use the HDMI from the Pi, but I could not get a stable connection on my Denon amp.

The top of this case is compatible with the bottom of this one:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/raspberry-pi-2-case-with-mounting-bracket

Which is based on this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740

In case you want to modify this design, you'll find the .stp file here;
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/hifiberry-digi-raspberry-pi2-case

4x M3 x 16mm to mount the Pi+HiFiBerry
print the 4 spacers to go between the Pi and the HifiBerry
4x M3 x 40mm + locknuts to close the case (assuming you use the wallframe/foot)

comments.text: Okay so I cut my own holes with a dremel and finally have a gorgeous case.  Then.....it doesn't friggin close.  I have now been to 3 hardware stores to find 2 that even carry m3 nylock nuts.  Whether it's nylocks or standard m3 nuts, 2 brands and they simply don't fit and I've been literally carving the holes with a darn knife for an hour and still don't even have a single nut in deep enough to catch the screw.  It's not that off, just enough to make them not fit but given the depth on these, it's a real pain to try to carve that deep.
comments.author: CollinChaffin

comments.text: Okay so for those who also have this issue, my fallback was to break out a drillbit slightly larger than the hex holes and just drilling them out about half depth, enough to drop the nuts in.  Then, I did have to stick a tweezer end in next to the M3 nut to prevent it's spinning just long enough to quickly get it to begin tightening.
comments.author: CollinChaffin

comments.text: I love this case so much I just started the 2nd one to print and went to dry-fit in my pi to be absolutely CRUSHED and find out that this does not seem to match the standard Digi+ with TOSLINK that is currently sold everywhere today (including mine).
comments.author: CollinChaffin

comments.text: I see now that the branded Hifiberry is the one this is spaced for, whereas what looks like the generic reference board which is even sold as branded under diff names on Amazon is the one I have where the TOSLINK is spaced further and the components, albeit the exact same, are simply laid out differently.

title: Substitute roller for Continous Ink system (Ciss) from City Ink Express / Fotorite (on eBay)

description.text:
I have got the roll, which is used to plug the ink channels, when the printer is not used, worn out and finally broken. So here is the printed substitute.

I have bought the original system from http://www.cityinkexpress.co.uk
on eBay (http://www.ebay.com/usr/cityinkexpress)

I have printed it in high resolution on a several raft layers as this is a small and delicate part, which has to roll well. I have also applied a little bit of LR3 grease to make it rolling smoothly in the CISS.

author: glassy

description.text: An articulated model of the Guren Mk.2 mech from the anime Code Geass. As with the Lancelot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961147) model I made some parts need to be printed twice due to the symmetry of the model (Landspinner, Thighs, Foot), pivoting parts like the fingers on each hand, the wheels and the elbow of the right arm use 22 gauge wire so they can pivot. Some of the details were edited for the inclusion of ball and socket joints, and for ease of print and the parts were assembled with superglue. I ended up putting a lot of craft foam for padding in the connection between the shoulder and right arm so the model could actually hold poses, other joint also have thin foam stripes inside the socket to stiffen them. Everything was modeled on 123D Design and Printed with 10% fill on a Printrbot Play.

remixed_from.author: GeoDave
remixed_from.title: End Cap for 3/4" Electrical Conduit Pipe on Mostly Printed CNC

title: Power Supply cover for the model that came with the kit for the Mostly Printed CNC

description.text:
The back cover of this is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:258715

I decided to put a cover over the connections to the power supply I received in the kit for the Mostly Printed CNC. I found the one above for the same power supply, but I removed the holes for the Switch, Voltmeter or Ammeter as I was not using them.

I also changed the hole size and location for the AC & DC wire, to use the Electrical Endcaps I designed instead of grommets for the holes: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:940458 I included the openscad file for endcaps & the modified version of the P/S back. I did not change the front cover, but included the original STL file of it here. If you want the switch, voltmeter & Ammeter holes, use the original design listed above.

I included a elongated version of the Wire cap & a shorter version. I needed the longer version for the AC line, since I had stripped the outer wire further. I put crimps on the wires & needed 12v wire the same as the AC hole. You can change the Diameter of either hole to what you want in the openscad file.

author: GeoDave

description.text: This is a simple endstop mount for the Z axis for the SeeMeCNC H-1.1. It should also work for the H-1 and any other printer that uses 1/4" rods for the z guides. Should print off fine in both PLA and ABS

You can either simply snap this on the 1/4 rod, or drill a hole for whatever bolt size you want to use it with. The endstop I use has some self tapping screws that I just fit through the holes in the endstop and screw into the mount.
this is the little enclosure for the computer
It's a dragon fly. It came out very very wrong. It was a bad design error and had no problem with a ToM machine.

title: wayler wind surf board foot strap insert

description.text:
Going on vacation I wanted to take my 30 year old wayler wind surf board along. It is still a very usefull board in general but it turned out the foot straps did not survive time. I managed to find two reasonable secondhand ones but that left me with no rear foot straps. I made inserts for the wayler board that fits the special foot strap hole so that alternative foot straps can be used.

It's a bit dificult to fit but it holds beautifully.

It is printed with Dutch Filaments; flex 45 a flexible polyester variant.
Printsettings; temperature 250 degrees, bed temperature 90 degrees, infill 85%.
